A '''democratic empire''' is a political state which conducts its ''internal'' affairs [[democratically]] (i.e. with respect for its citizens and their collective will) but ''externally'' its policies have a striking resemblance to [[empire|imperial]] rule.
Democratic imperialism as such may in fact be a contradiction in terms as empires express themselves with aggression abroad and repression at home. The concept of a democratic empire can likewise be an instrument of [[social control]] as with [[ideology]] and ideological conditioning generally. Example of empires that have been described in this way are the [[British Empire]] and the [[United States of America]] based on some of its foreign affairs history (see [[American imperialism|American Empire]]).<ref>{{cite book |title=Democracy and empire; with studies of their psychological, economic, and moral foundations |chapter=The Democratic Empire |authorlink=Franklin Henry Giddings |last=Giddings |first=Franklin Henry |pages=3–12 |year=1900 |publisher=[[Macmillan & Co.]] |oclc=8770114 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Empires: the logic of world domination from ancient Rome to the United States |chapter=A democratic empire? |authorlink=Herfried Münkler |last=Münkler |first=Herfried |page=154–161 |year=2007 |publisher=[[Polity (publisher)|Polity]] |isbn=978-0-7456-3872-0 }}</ref>
